title: 2 Kings Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 8.

questions.question: Who told the woman to leave and sojourn in the land of the Philistines because of the coming famine?
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha
questions.explanation: Elisha instructed the woman to leave and sojourn in the land of the Philistines because of a coming famine (2 Kings 8:1).

questions.question: How many years did the famine last as mentioned in 2 Kings 8?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven years
questions.explanation: The famine was prophesied to last seven years (2 Kings 8:1).

questions.question: Where did the woman stay during the famine?
questions.correctAnswer: Land of the Philistines
questions.explanation: The woman and her household sojourned in the land of the Philistines for seven years (2 Kings 8:2).

questions.question: Who did the king talk to about the great things Elisha had done?
questions.correctAnswer: Gehazi
questions.explanation: The king spoke with Gehazi, the servant of Elisha, to hear about Elisha's great works (2 Kings 8:4).

questions.question: What did Gehazi say about the woman who cried to the king for her house and land?
options: She is the woman whose son Elisha restored to life
She is a widow from Israel
She is a servant of the king
questions.correctAnswer: She is the woman whose son Elisha restored to life
questions.explanation: Gehazi identified the woman as the one whose son Elisha restored to life (2 Kings 8:5).

questions.question: What did the king command after hearing the woman's story?
options: Restore all she had lost and the fruits of the field.
questions.correctAnswer: Restore all she had lost and the fruits of the field.
questions.explanation: The king ordered that all her property and produce be restored to her from the day she left the land (2 Kings 8:6).

questions.question: Who was sick when Elisha came to Damascus?
questions.correctAnswer: Benhadad king of Syria
questions.explanation: Benhadad king of Syria was sick when Elisha arrived at Damascus (2 Kings 8:7).

questions.question: What did King Benhadad ask Hazael to do when Elisha came?
options: Take a present to Elisha and ask if he will recover
questions.correctAnswer: Take a present to Elisha and ask if he will recover
questions.explanation: Benhadad told Hazael to take a present to Elisha and ask if he would recover from his illness (2 Kings 8:8).

questions.question: How did Elisha respond to the question about Benhadad’s recovery?
options: He will recover but will surely die
questions.correctAnswer: He will recover but will surely die
questions.explanation: Elisha said Benhadad may recover but the Lord showed him he would surely die (2 Kings 8:10).

questions.question: Why did Elisha weep when Hazael visited him?
options: Because Elisha knew the evil Hazael would do to Israel
Because he was sad for the woman
questions.correctAnswer: Because Elisha knew the evil Hazael would do to Israel
questions.explanation: Elisha wept because he knew the evil Hazael would do to Israel (2 Kings 8:11-12).

questions.question: True or False: Hazael denied he would do evil to the children of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hazael asked if he was a dog to do such a great evil, denying his future actions (2 Kings 8:13).

questions.question: True or False: Hazael killed King Benhadad and became king of Syria.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hazael killed Benhadad and reigned in his place (2 Kings 8:15).

questions.question: Who began to reign in Judah in the fifth year of Joram son of Ahab?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat
questions.explanation: Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat began to reign in Judah in that year (2 Kings 8:16).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jehoram walked in the way of the kings of ________, doing evil in the sight of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Jehoram walked in the way of the kings of Israel, doing evil (2 Kings 8:18).

questions.question: True or False: Edom revolted from Judah during the reign of Jehoram.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Edom revolted from Judah during Jehoram’s reign (2 Kings 8:20).

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does the story of the woman who fled to the land of the Philistines teach us about trusting God's guidance during difficult times?
options: Obedience to God's warning can lead to protection during trials
Ignoring God's instructions leads to immediate blessings
God discourages leaving one's homeland in trouble
Faith is unnecessary when facing famine
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's warning can lead to protection during trials
questions.explanation: Elisha told the woman to leave because the LORD had called a famine for seven years (2 Kings 8:1-2). Her obedience protected her household during the famine and resulted in restoration (2 Kings 8:3-6). This teaches us that trusting and obeying God's guidance in trials is wise and beneficial.

questions.question: What biblical principle about stewardship and integrity can we learn from the king's decision regarding the woman's land and house?
options: Restoration of what is rightfully lost reflects God's justice
Kings should keep possessions of those who leave
Property rights are insignificant in times of famine
Wealth accumulation is the highest priority
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration of what is rightfully lost reflects God's justice
questions.explanation: The king commanded an officer to restore all that belonged to the woman, including the fruits of the field, from the day she left until now (2 Kings 8:6). This shows the importance of honesty, justice, and integrity in stewardship and leadership.

questions.question: In the encounter between Elisha and Hazael, what lesson about discerning God's will and the consequences of sin is illustrated?
options: God reveals future consequences of evil to His servants
Prophets should conceal bad news to keep peace
Sin has no consequences on others
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals future consequences of evil to His servants
questions.explanation: Elisha wept because he knew the evil that Hazael would do to Israel (2 Kings 8:11-12). This demonstrates how God reveals His will to His prophets, including the judgment and consequences of sin, emphasizing the need for repentance and vigilance.

questions.question: What does Hazael’s reaction to Elisha’s prophecy show us about humility and self-awareness?
options: He questioned his ability to commit great evil
He immediately repented and changed his ways
He arrogantly accepted the prophecy without reflection
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned his ability to commit great evil
questions.explanation: Hazael asked, 'But what, is thy servant a dog, that he should do this great thing?' (2 Kings 8:13), showing initial disbelief and lack of self-awareness regarding his future evil acts, which teaches us the importance of humility and self-examination to avoid sin.

questions.question: How does the transition of kingship from Benhadad to Hazael illustrate God’s sovereignty over earthly rulers and events?
options: God permits and orchestrates leadership changes according to His plan
Kingship changes happen randomly without divine purpose
God always preserves wicked rulers indefinitely
Humans control all political outcomes without God’s involvement
questions.correctAnswer: God permits and orchestrates leadership changes according to His plan
questions.explanation: Elisha foretold Benhadad’s death and Hazael’s rise to kingship (2 Kings 8:10, 13-15), showing that God is sovereign over rulers and history, guiding events to fulfill His purposes, reminding believers to trust God's control over worldly affairs.

questions.question: What can we learn about walking in obedience or disobedience from Jehoram king of Judah's example?
options: Walking in evil ways leads to negative consequences despite blessings
The king’s actions had no impact on Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in evil ways leads to negative consequences despite blessings
questions.explanation: Jehoram walked in the ways of Ahab and did evil in the LORD’s sight (2 Kings 8:18), yet God did not destroy Judah for David’s sake (2 Kings 8:19). This teaches about the seriousness of obedience, the consequences of sin, and God’s mercy and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does the revolt of Edom during Jehoram’s reign teach about perseverance and dealing with trials in leadership?
options: Leaders must actively respond to rebellion with courage and strategy
Ignoring rebellion leads to God's approval
Trials in leadership mean abandonment by God
Revolt is always a sign of divine approval
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must actively respond to rebellion with courage and strategy
questions.explanation: Jehoram went with his chariots and smote the Edomites by night (2 Kings 8:21), showing the need for perseverance, courage, and wise action in trials, even when facing rebellion or opposition in leadership.

questions.question: How does Ahaziah’s reign and his relationship with the house of Ahab illustrate the importance of spiritual heritage and family influence in faith?
options: Family influence can lead to following evil paths if not rooted in God
Family has no impact on spiritual decisions
Ignoring family heritage is always best
questions.correctAnswer: Family influence can lead to following evil paths if not rooted in God
questions.explanation: Ahaziah walked in the ways of the house of Ahab because he was their son-in-law (2 Kings 8:27), showing how family and marriage can influence spiritual direction, underscoring the need for individual faithfulness and discernment.

questions.question: True or False: Elisha’s instructions to the woman to leave during the famine and her obedience demonstrate the value of trusting God’s Word even when circumstances are uncertain.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Elisha told the woman to leave because the LORD had called for a famine (2 Kings 8:1), and she obeyed (2 Kings 8:2). Her trust in God's Word led to her preservation, teaching us to have faith and obedience amid uncertainty.

questions.question: True or False: Hazael’s response to Elisha’s prophecy was one of immediate repentance and turning away from evil.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hazael questioned if he could do such evil (2 Kings 8:13) but did not repent. Instead, he later killed Benhadad and became king (2 Kings 8:15), showing no immediate repentance, which warns us about the danger of ignoring God’s warnings.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God’s guidance during a prolonged trial. Based on 2 Kings 8, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s warnings and instructions, even if difficult, lead to protection and restoration
Trials mean God has abandoned you
Ignore God’s guidance and rely on yourself
God’s promises only apply to kings
questions.correctAnswer: God’s warnings and instructions, even if difficult, lead to protection and restoration
questions.explanation: The woman obeyed Elisha’s warning about the famine and was preserved (2 Kings 8:1-6). This teaches that trusting and obeying God’s word during trials brings protection and eventual restoration.

questions.question: How does the example of Jehoram’s reign encourage us regarding the importance of personal holiness in leadership and family life?
options: Walking in evil ways harms not only oneself but the people under one’s care
Leadership has no bearing on family spirituality
Personal holiness is optional for leaders
Evil conduct is excusable if inherited
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in evil ways harms not only oneself but the people under one’s care
questions.explanation: Jehoram did evil as king and was influenced by his marriage to Ahab’s daughter (2 Kings 8:18), leading to consequences like revolts (2 Kings 8:20-22). This underscores the need for holiness in leadership and family to protect others.

questions.question: What biblical truth about God’s mercy can be drawn from the fact that Judah was not destroyed despite Jehoram’s evil reign?
options: God’s promises and mercy can preserve us for the sake of His servants
Mercy depends on human merit alone
God’s covenant is conditional only on kings
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promises and mercy can preserve us for the sake of His servants
questions.explanation: Although Jehoram did evil, the LORD did not destroy Judah because of His promise to David (2 Kings 8:19), teaching us about God’s mercy and faithfulness despite our shortcomings.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elisha told Hazael to say to Benhadad, 'Thou mayest certainly recover: howbeit the LORD hath shewed me that he shall surely ____.'
questions.correctAnswer: die
questions.explanation: Elisha told Hazael to say Benhadad may recover, but the LORD showed Elisha that he would surely die (2 Kings 8:10). This shows the tension between human hope and divine judgment.

questions.question: How does the interaction between the king of Israel and Gehazi emphasize the importance of recounting God’s works for encouragement and witness?
options: Sharing testimonies of God’s miracles strengthens faith and validates His power
God’s works should be kept secret
Human achievements are more important than God’s works
Stories of God’s miracles discourage believers
questions.correctAnswer: Sharing testimonies of God’s miracles strengthens faith and validates His power
questions.explanation: The king asked Gehazi to tell him all the great things Elisha had done, including raising the dead (2 Kings 8:4-5), showing the power of testimony for faith-building and witness.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 8.

questions.question: What was the duration of the famine that Elisha foretold to the woman whose son he restored to life?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven years
questions.explanation: Elisha told the woman that the LORD had called for a famine that would last seven years (2 Kings 8:1).

questions.question: Where did the woman sojourn during the famine as instructed by Elisha?
questions.correctAnswer: Land of the Philistines
questions.explanation: The woman went with her household to sojourn in the land of the Philistines for seven years as Elisha instructed (2 Kings 8:2).

questions.question: To whom did the king speak about the great things Elisha had done, including restoring a dead body to life?
questions.correctAnswer: Gehazi
questions.explanation: The king spoke with Gehazi, Elisha's servant, asking him to recount the great deeds Elisha had performed (2 Kings 8:4-5).

questions.question: What action did the king take after the woman requested the restoration of her house and land?
options: He appointed an officer to restore all her property
He gave her a monetary compensation
questions.correctAnswer: He appointed an officer to restore all her property
questions.explanation: The king commanded an officer to restore all that was hers and the fruits of the field since she left the land (2 Kings 8:6).

questions.question: Who was the king of Syria when Elisha came to Damascus, and what was his condition?
questions.correctAnswer: Benhadad, who was sick
questions.explanation: Elisha came to Damascus when Benhadad, the king of Syria, was sick (2 Kings 8:7).

questions.question: What present did Hazael bring to Elisha when sent to inquire about the king's recovery?
options: Forty camels' burden of every good thing of Damascus
A letter sealed with the king's signet
questions.correctAnswer: Forty camels' burden of every good thing of Damascus
questions.explanation: Hazael brought a lavish present consisting of forty camels' burden of every good thing of Damascus to Elisha (2 Kings 8:9).

questions.question: What paradox did Elisha reveal about Benhadad's health and fate?
options: He will recover but surely die
He will live many more years
questions.correctAnswer: He will recover but surely die
questions.explanation: Elisha told Hazael that Benhadad might recover initially, but the LORD had shown him that he would surely die (2 Kings 8:10).

questions.question: Why did Elisha weep when Hazael came to him?
options: Because he knew the evil Hazael would do to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because he knew the evil Hazael would do to Israel
questions.explanation: Elisha wept because he foresaw the terrible violence Hazael would commit against the children of Israel (2 Kings 8:11-12).

questions.question: What did Elisha predict about Hazael's future status?
options: He would be king over Syria
questions.correctAnswer: He would be king over Syria
questions.explanation: Elisha revealed that the LORD had shown him that Hazael would become king over Syria (2 Kings 8:13).

questions.question: How did Hazael kill King Benhadad according to the text?
options: By smothering him with a wet cloth
questions.correctAnswer: By smothering him with a wet cloth
questions.explanation: Hazael took a thick cloth, dipped it in water, and spread it on Benhadad's face, causing his death (2 Kings 8:15).

questions.question: Who began to reign in Judah in the fifth year of Joram son of Ahab's reign in Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram, son of Jehoshaphat
questions.explanation: Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat began to reign in Judah during the fifth year of Joram son of Ahab king of Israel (2 Kings 8:16).

questions.question: How did Jehoram, king of Judah, conduct his reign according to the chapter?
options: He walked in the way of the kings of Israel and did evil
He was righteous and followed the LORD
He was a peaceful and just ruler
questions.correctAnswer: He walked in the way of the kings of Israel and did evil
questions.explanation: Jehoram walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, doing evil in the sight of the LORD (2 Kings 8:18).

questions.question: Which regions revolted from Judah during Jehoram's reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Edom and Libnah
questions.explanation: Edom revolted from Judah's hand, and at the same time Libnah also revolted (2 Kings 8:20, 8:22).

questions.question: How old was Ahaziah when he began to reign, and how long did he reign?
options: Twenty-two years old, reigned one year
Thirty-two years old, reigned eight years
Twenty years old, reigned five years
Thirty years old, reigned two years
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-two years old, reigned one year
questions.explanation: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned one year in Jerusalem (2 Kings 8:26).

questions.question: True or False: Ahaziah walked in the ways of the house of Ahab and did evil in the sight of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ahaziah walked in the way of the house of Ahab and did evil in the sight of the LORD (2 Kings 8:27).

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Elisha reveal to the woman whose son he restored about the coming famine?
options: The famine will last three years
The famine will last seven years
The famine will last ten years
questions.correctAnswer: The famine will last seven years
questions.explanation: Elisha told the woman to go sojourn because the LORD had called for a famine that would last seven years (2 Kings 8:1). This reflects God's sovereign control over natural events, consistent with His control seen in Genesis 41:30-31 and Revelation 6:5-6.

questions.question: Where did the woman and her household sojourn during the famine?
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines' land
questions.explanation: The woman obeyed Elisha's command and sojourned in the land of the Philistines for seven years during the famine (2 Kings 8:2). This shows God's providential protection of His people in foreign lands, similar to Joseph in Egypt (Genesis 39-41) and Daniel in Babylon (Daniel 1).

questions.question: How did the king respond when the woman cried out for the restoration of her house and land?
options: He appointed an officer to restore her property and its fruits
He gave her a small portion of land
questions.correctAnswer: He appointed an officer to restore her property and its fruits
questions.explanation: Upon hearing the woman's plea, the king instructed an officer to restore all that was hers, including the fruits of the field since she left (2 Kings 8:6). This reflects God's justice and His concern for restitution, paralleling principles seen in Exodus 22:14-15 and Luke 19:8.

questions.question: What was King Benhadad of Syria's condition when Elisha came to Damascus?
questions.correctAnswer: Sick
questions.explanation: Benhadad was sick when Elisha arrived in Damascus (2 Kings 8:7). This situation sets the stage for divine revelation, similar to how God reveals His will through prophets during times of kingly weakness (e.g., Hezekiah's illness in Isaiah 38).

questions.question: What question did Hazael bring to Elisha from King Benhadad?
options: Shall I recover of this disease?
Should I make peace with Judah?
Will I live to see the next year?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall I recover of this disease?
questions.explanation: Hazael asked Elisha if King Benhadad would recover from his illness (2 Kings 8:9). This inquiry reflects the reliance on divine revelation through prophets for matters of life and death, consistent with biblical prophetic ministry (1 Kings 17:17-24; Luke 7:2-10).

questions.question: What was Elisha’s prophecy regarding King Benhadad’s illness?
options: He will fully recover and live long
He will die despite initially recovering
He will be cured by Hazael
He will be healed through prayer
questions.correctAnswer: He will die despite initially recovering
questions.explanation: Elisha told Hazael to say the king would recover, but God had shown him that Benhadad would surely die (2 Kings 8:10). This demonstrates God's sovereign knowledge of future events (Isaiah 46:9-10) and the prophetic role in declaring God's will (Jeremiah 1:5).

questions.question: Why did Elisha weep when Hazael visited him?
options: Because he foresaw the evil Hazael would do to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because he foresaw the evil Hazael would do to Israel
questions.explanation: Elisha wept because he knew of the great evil Hazael would commit against Israel, including burning strongholds and killing many (2 Kings 8:11-12). This reveals God's concern for His people and judgment against sin (Psalm 94:1-3; Ezekiel 9:4-6).

questions.question: What was Hazael’s response when Elisha predicted his future kingship and evil deeds?
options: He accepted and promised to repent
He denied he would do such great evil
questions.correctAnswer: He denied he would do such great evil
questions.explanation: Hazael questioned, 'Is thy servant a dog, that he should do this great thing?' denying the evil he would do, though Elisha affirmed he would be king over Syria (2 Kings 8:13). This highlights human denial of sin contrasted with divine foreknowledge (Romans 3:10-18).

questions.question: How did Hazael become king of Syria?
options: He killed Benhadad by smothering him with a wet cloth
He was elected by the people
questions.correctAnswer: He killed Benhadad by smothering him with a wet cloth
questions.explanation: Hazael killed Benhadad by placing a wet cloth over his face, causing his death, and then reigned in his stead (2 Kings 8:15). This act illustrates the biblical theme of violent usurpation and human sinfulness (Psalm 37:38; 2 Samuel 3:27).

questions.question: Who began to reign in Judah in the fifth year of Joram son of Ahab, king of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat
questions.explanation: Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat began to reign in Judah during the fifth year of Joram king of Israel (2 Kings 8:16). His reign shows the interconnectedness of Israel and Judah's royal lines and the ongoing covenantal promises to David (2 Samuel 7:16; Psalm 89:3-4).

questions.question: What is said about Jehoram’s conduct as king of Judah?
options: He walked in righteousness and faithfulness
He walked in the way of the kings of Israel and did evil
He was neutral in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: He walked in the way of the kings of Israel and did evil
questions.explanation: Jehoram walked in the ways of the kings of Israel and did evil because he married Ahab's daughter (2 Kings 8:18). This reflects the dangers of syncretism and apostasy, consistent with warnings in Deuteronomy 7:3-4 and 2 Chronicles 21:6-7.

questions.question: Why did the LORD not destroy Judah despite Jehoram’s evil?
options: For David His servant's sake and His promise to maintain a light for David and his children
Because Judah was too small to judge
questions.correctAnswer: For David His servant's sake and His promise to maintain a light for David and his children
questions.explanation: God spared Judah for the sake of David and His covenant promise to keep a light for David and his descendants (2 Kings 8:19). This underscores God's faithfulness to His covenant (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Psalm 89:34-37; Luke 1:32-33).

questions.question: What significant political event happened during Jehoram’s reign in relation to Edom?
options: Edom became a vassal to Judah
Edom revolted and made a king over themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Edom revolted and made a king over themselves
questions.explanation: During Jehoram’s reign, Edom revolted from Judah’s control and set up their own king (2 Kings 8:20). This event illustrates the consequences of disobedience and the weakening of God's people when unfaithful (Judges 2:14-15; Hosea 13:1-4).

questions.question: Who succeeded Jehoram as king of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Ahaziah
questions.explanation: Jehoram was succeeded by his son Ahaziah as king of Judah (2 Kings 8:24). This succession continues the Davidic line, fulfilling God's promises despite the kings' moral failures (1 Chronicles 3:11; Romans 1:3).

questions.question: What is notable about Ahaziah’s lineage and conduct as king of Judah?
options: He was righteous and followed God faithfully
He was the son-in-law of Ahab and did evil like the house of Ahab
questions.correctAnswer: He was the son-in-law of Ahab and did evil like the house of Ahab
questions.explanation: Ahaziah, being the son-in-law of Ahab, walked in the ways of Ahab’s house and did evil in the sight of the LORD (2 Kings 8:26-27). This highlights the spiritual dangers of ungodly alliances, consistent with warnings in 1 Kings 21 and 2 Chronicles 22:3.
